Executive Summary

Sysco Kansas City, Inc.



Risk Management Plan Executive Summary



General Executive Summary:



1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. is committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as the design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate control measures to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur; our highly trained employees are on hand to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also completely coordinated with the Olathe Fire Department, who provide our emergency response services.



2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled:



We have one extremely hazardous substance present at our facility that is subject to the Process Safety and Risk Management Planning regulations. That substance is Ammonia (anhydrous). The maximum inventory of Ammonia (anhydrous) that is expected to be present at this facility, based upon process and operational requirements is approximately 17,000 pounds.



3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. has taken the following steps as required by 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA. Our Ammonia (anhydrous) process is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management standard under 29 CFR 1910.119. Our facility is also subject to the EPA Emergency Planning and Community Right To Know Act (EPCRA) Section 302 reporting requirements. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place.



Employee Participation:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. believes that process safety management and accident prevention ar

e a team effort. Company employees and contractors are urged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements for the ammonia refrigeration system. In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the implementation of the RMP regulation, including information resulting from process hazard analyses, in particular.



Process Safety Information:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. gathered all required process safety information prior to conducting a comprehensive process hazard analysis. The process safety information is documented in the PSM/RMP release prevention program for all refrigeration equipment and ancillary systems. The information is documentation to assure recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices for this process meets the industry standards.



Process Hazard Analysis:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. uses the What-If Checklist method of Process Hazard Analysis to identify and correct any issues that can affect the safety and/or mechanical integrity of the ammonia refrigeration system. A team of personnel representing engineering, construction, operations, safety, management and labor convene at least every 5 years to complete or revise the Process Hazard Analysis.



Operating Procedures:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial start-up, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and start-up after a turnaround. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.



Training:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes. New employees involved in the process receive basic training in process operations, followed by on-the-job s

upervision until they are deemed competent to work independently. Refresher training is provided at least every 3 years and more frequently as needed.



Contractors:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. occasionally hires contractors for specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is completed. Sysco Kansas City, Inc. has a strict policy of informing contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the ammonia refrigeration system. Contractors are also trained regarding the procedures for emergency notification, evacuation and employee accountability, should an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous) occur.



Pre-Startup Reviews:



Pre-startup reviews are initiated for new processes and when modifications of established processes are made as a regular practice at Sysco Kansas City, Inc. These reviews are conducted for process equipment, procedures, and facility changes to confirm construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe start-up prior to placing equipment into operation.



Mechanical Integrity:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. completes documented maintenance inspections and test on process equipment to ensure proper operation. Process equipment examined by these checks includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping system, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified personnel carry out maintenance operations with special training in maintenance practices. Furthermore, personnel who conduct, operate, or maintain the ammonia refrigeration system are given specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a timely manner.



Hot Work Procedures:



Procedures are in place at Sysco Kansas City, Inc. to insure that any hot work performed on or near the ammonia refrigeration system is approved by management a

nd safe. Prior to approving any hot work that could affect the safety and/or mechanical integrity of the ammonia refrigeration system, the area is inspected, fire and emergency equipment is prepared and a fire watch person is in place. A written hot work permit is issued for all areas of the facility that are not designed as "designated hot work locations".



Management of Change:



Written procedures are in place at Sysco Kansas City, Inc. to manage change in process chemicals, technology, equipment and processes. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employees whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process operations, are promptly made aware of, and given, training to deal with the modifications.



Incident Investigation:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Ammonia (anhydrous) including near miss/close call events. These investigations are conducted to identify the circumstances leading up to the incident that could have been prevented, and to establish corrective actions to prevent the release or near-miss from recurring. All accident/incident reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.



Emergency Planning and Response:

Sysco Kansas City, Inc. is included in the written community emergency response plan. Emergency response is coordinated with local response agencies in event an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous) occurs. The facility also has its own emergency action plan that allows for trained employees to conduct defensive activities to contain or stop small ammonia releases. This action plan includes procedures for informing the public and local response agencies in the event of a release of Ammonia (anhydrous). The emergency action plan is primarily to notify employees about emergency conditions that require evacuations or shelter to in place.



Compliance Audits:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. conducts audits intern

al on a regular basis and third party audits at least every three years to determine whether the provisions required by the PSM/RMP regulation are being implemented with diligence. These audits also assure any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are completed in a timely manner.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:



Sysco Kansas City, Inc. believes that all man-made accidents and incidents are preventable. This goal can be achieved through the safe and legally compliant design, installation, maintenance and operation of our ammonia refrigeration system. Recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices are routinely reviewed as part of the continuous improvement effort. In addition, we will continue our annual facility evacuation drills and planning/training site visits with the Olathe Fire Department in the future.
